coredata.dc:title: Modeling ischemia with finite elements and automated machine learning

abstract.ce:para: The main purpose of this study was to noninvasively detect and localize ischemic cardiac disease using the finite element method (FEM) in combination with machine learning approach. The forward FEM simulations of cardiac ischemia in different heart segments enabled the creation of a virtual database which consisted of corresponding body surface potentials. Two sets of experiments were performed on the database in order to select the best method for determining the existence of ischemia and then to predict the location of ischemia. Using Auto-WEKA and R caret package, several machine learning algorithms were tested. The best first phase model returned the classification accuracy of 95.3%, while the best second phase model determined the correct ischemia location with 95% accuracy. Considerable modeling and computational time are needed to create a training database and perform training, but once trained, the models will instantly return results. Thus, the main advantage of the proposed approach to ischemic detection and localization is a real-time availability of results and a novel, two-phase design which guides the selection of an adequate treatment.

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development of Serbia
Serbian Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development
Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development, and European commission

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The authors acknowledge the project “Automatic detection and localization of ischemia by the use of data mining algorithms” (BI-RS/16-17-052) which was financially supported by the Slovenian Research Agency and Serbian Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development. Marko Robnik-Šikonja was also supported by the Slovenian Research Agency (ARRS) through research programme P2-0209. Miloš Radović, Smiljana Đorović, Bojana Anđelković-Ćirković and Nenad Filipović are also supported with grants III41007 and ON174028 from Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development of Serbia . This project has received funding from the European Union´s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No 777204 (SilicoFCM). Marko Robnik-Šikonja received his Ph.D. in computer science in 2001 from the University of Ljubljana. He is Professor at the University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Computer and Information Science and Head of Artificial Intelligence Chair. His research interest include machine learning, data and text mining, knowledge discovery, network analytics and their practical applications. He is a (co)author of more than 100 publications in scientific journals and international conferences. He authors and maintains three open-source analytical tools in R. Miloš Radović received his PhD from the Faculty of Engineering, University of Kragujevac in 2015. Since 2009 he works as a researcher at Research and Development Center for Bioengineering in Kragujevac, Serbia. His research is focused on data mining and machine learning. He participates in several projects funded by the Serbian Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development, DARPA and European commission. Smiljana Đorović was born in Kragujevac, Serbia, in 1992. She received her Bachelor and Master’s diploma from the Faculty of Engineering, University of Kragujevac. She is currently a PhD student at the same Faculty. Her research interests are in the area of computational modelling and analysis of cardiovascular diseases, based on Finite Element Method. She participates in the projects funded by the Serbian Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development, and European commission. Bojana Anđelković Ćirković was born in Kragujevac, Serbia, in 1986. She received the Graduate degree in 2010 from the Department of Mathematics and Informatics, Faculty of Science, University of Kragujevac. She is currently working toward the PhD degree at the Faculty of Engineering, University of Kragujevac. Her research interests include reasoning about uncertainty, data mining and machine learning with application in biomedical engineering. Nenad Filipović received his PhD from the University of Kragujevac, Serbia in 1999. He was Research Associate at Harvard School of Public Health in Boston, US. He is a Full Professor at the Faculty of Engineering, University of Kragujevac, Serbia. His research interests are in the area of biomedical engineering, cardiovascular diseases, fluid-structure interaction, biomechanics, multi-scale modeling, data mining, software engineering, parallel computing, computational chemistry and bioprocess modeling. He is the author and co-author of 6 textbooks and 3 monographs in English, the author and co-author of over 150 publications, over 90 scientific papers in peer reviewed journals, the author and co-author of over 10 software for modelling with finite element method and discrete methods from fluid mechanics and multiphysics. He also leads a number of national and international projects in EU and US in area of bioengineering and software development.

abstract.ce:para: The main purpose of this study was to noninvasively detect and localize ischemic cardiac disease using the finite element method (FEM) in combination with machine learning approach. The forward FEM simulations of cardiac ischemia in different heart segments enabled the creation of a virtual database which consisted of corresponding body surface potentials. Two sets of experiments were performed on the database in order to select the best method for determining the existence of ischemia and then to predict the location of ischemia. The best first phase model returned the classification accuracy of 95.3%, while the best second phase model determined the correct ischemia location with 95% accuracy. Considerable modeling and computational time are needed to create a training database and perform training, but once trained, the models will instantly return results. Thus, the main advantage of the proposed approach to ischemic detection and localization is a real-time availability of results and a novel, two-phase design which guides the selection of an adequate treatment.
